abstracts.cdata!:
The overall achievement of the program
            objectives is rated as substantial. The main reason for
            success was the strong ownership of reform agenda and
            sustained commitment by the Malian Government to strengthen
            its policy reforms and its open dialogue with the Bank. The
            following factors, subject to Government control, positively
            affected the program implementation: (i) strong commitment
            of the Government and its open dialogue with the Bank-; (ii)
            the Government's clear vision of the objectives of the
            economic reform program and its willingness to adopt the
            appropriate means to achieve the objectives; (iii) an
            effective mass media campaign to inform and educate the
            public about the merits and consequences of the devaluation
            and the accompanying policy reforms; and (iv) effective
            utilization of available funds from other donors which were
            used to help design and implement economic reforms. Overall,
            IDA's experience with the ERC has been positive. The
            following observations emerge from the ERC's
            implementation record and outcome: (i) Strong Government
            Commitment. A sine qua non for success in the design and
            implementation of an emergency financing program is strong
            and sustained Government commitment to the policy reform
            package, as well as dynamic leadership and full ownership of
            the program by the Government. (ii) Up-front
            Conditionalities and Single Tranche Disbursement. As a
            short-term financing instrument, the ERC was well designed
            to respond on time to the immediate constraints faced by
            Mali after the devaluation. (iii) Retroactive Financing. In
            light of the urgent and extraordinary nature of the ERC, the
            Bank decided on an exceptional basis to extend the period of
            retroactive financing to August 2, 1993, about nine months
            prior to credit effectiveness, in lieu of the normal four
            months guidelines.  This decision led to faster disbursement
            arrangements and facilitated quick and easy availability of
            the credit proceeds.
